value.name: Korean VLBI Network - Wikipedia
value.snippet: The Korean VLBI Network (KVN) is a radio astronomy observatory located in South Korea. It comprises three 21-meter radio telescopes that function as an interferometer, using the technique of very-long-baseline interferometry (VLBI).

value.name: Korean VLBI Network station contact information | EVLBI
value.snippet: Korean VLBI Network station contact information Yonsei, Ulsan, Tamna Internet http://kvn.kasi.re.kr Phone numbers: +82 42 865 3332 (KASI headquarters) +82 42 869 5825 (KVN AOC) +82 2 362 8871 (KVN Yonsei observatory) +82 52 247 6491 (KVN Ulsan observatory) +82 64 738 1042 (KVN Tamna observatory) Fax numbers: +82 42 865 3304 (KVN AOC)

value.name: The Korean VLBI Network Project | SpringerLink
value.snippet: Korean VLBI Network (KVN) is a mm-VLBI network construction project of Korea Astronomy Observatory. During the (first) project period (2001 - 2007), three observatories are going to be constructed at Seoul (Yonsei Univ.), Ulsan (Univ. of Ulsan), and Jeju (Tamna Univ.).

value.name: Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute
value.snippet: The Korean VLBI Network (KVN) is a very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) network in Korea operating at millimeter wavelengths. It consists of three 21-m radio telescopes located in Seoul, in Ulsan, and on the Jeju Island, Korea: KVN Yonsei Radio Observatory (KY), KVN Ulsan Radio Observatory (KU), and KVN Tamna Radio Observatory (KT).

value.name: Korean VLBI Network (KVN) - Taeduk Radio Astronomy Observatory
value.snippet: The KVN antennas are controlled remotely from the Arrary Operation Center (AOC) in East Asia VLBI Center, KASI, Daejeon. The KVN stations are connected with the AOC through high speed dedicated network, KREONET (Korea Research Environment Open NETwork).

value.name: European VLBI Network - Wikipedia
value.snippet: The European VLBI Network (EVN) is a network of radio telescopes located primarily in Europe and Asia, with additional antennas in South Africa and Puerto Rico, which performs very high angular resolution observations of cosmic radio sources using very-long-baseline interferometry (VLBI).
